message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including abdominal pain, loose stools, and fever, suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The CT scan revealed focal inflammation in the terminal ileum and transverse colon. Non-caseating granulomas are a histologic finding specific for Crohn’s disease, one type of IBD. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts is a common finding in ulcerative colitis, another type of IBD. Intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are seen in viral infections, but this patient’s stool tests for infection were negative.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and CT scan findings suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Non-caseating granulomas are a key finding in Crohn's disease, the more likely of the two main types of IBD. The other options are nonspecific findings and may also be seen in other conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and laboratory findings suggest inflammation. The CT scan showed thickening of the terminal ileum and transverse colon, indicating Crohn's disease. The most specific finding for Crohn's disease is non-caseating granulomas on biopsy specimens. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts is seen in acute colitis, inflammation of the terminal ileum is not specific to any particular diagnosis, and intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are seen in viral infections.

The symptoms and CT scan suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), with non-caseating granulomas being the most specific finding for Crohn's disease, a type of IBD. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts, inflammation of the terminal ileum, and intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies can be seen in other gastrointestinal diseases but are not specific to Crohn's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan findings suggest inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) with Crohn's disease being the most likely diagnosis. Non-caseating granulomas, found in Crohn's disease, are more specific than neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts or inflammation of the terminal ileum. Intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are associated with viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, CT scan findings, and biopsy suggest Crohn's disease, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts is seen in acute colitis. Inflammation of the terminal ileum is seen in both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are seen in viral infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain, loose stools, and fever suggest inflammatory bowel disease, and the CT scan showing mural thickening and surrounding fat stranding support this diagnosis. The most specific finding for inflammatory bowel disease is non-caseating granulomas on biopsy, which are not present in other diseases like infections or ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, CT scan, and biopsy results suggest a diagnosis of Crohn’s disease. Non-caseating granulomas are the most specific finding for Crohn’s disease. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts can be seen in multiple types of colitis. Inflammation of the terminal ileum is a common finding in Crohn’s disease but it’s not specific. Intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are not associated with Crohn’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan suggest Crohn's disease. Non-caseating granulomas are a hallmark finding of Crohn's disease, while the other options are not specific for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, laboratory studies, and imaging findings suggest Crohn's disease, which is characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Neutrophilic inflammation of the crypts can be seen in infectious colitis, but stool studies were negative. Inflammation of the terminal ileum can be seen in both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, but non-caseating granulomas are specific to Crohn's disease. Intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies are seen in viral infections but are not specific for any particular diagnosis in this case.
